posts.name: C.Villano
posts.cooked: I just recently got Altair Inspire for one year, and to start I tried importing a baseplate model, in an STL format, that another team member made through Onshape for a swerve robot to try out stress testing and topology/topography optimization. I had some trouble with stress testing at first, but I did manage to figure out how to do it. However, when I tried using the topology/topography optimization, the software gave me the error “Invalid Geometry.” Does anyone know how I could remedy this? Or at least know what the problem is?

Legokaiju:

However, when I tried using the topology/topography optimization, the software gave me the error “Invalid Geometry.” Does anyone know how I could remedy this? Or at least know what the problem is?

Are you at all familiar with FEA at all? If not, you need to learn it first before you have any hope of performing successful analysis. FEA will very frequently throw errors and you need to be familiar with FEA theory to properly resolve many of them/

I wouldn’t be surprised if a singularity of some form or improper geometry is causing this error.

posts.name: James Dagg
posts.cooked:
You said you imported the file as STL.   STL is only facet data and you may have some bad facets.  Moreover, it’s not a great choice if you want to work with geometry well in Inspire.  A better choice is to read true geometry from OnShape (or any CAD system) either using their native files or a standard neutral format like STEP or Parasolid XT.   Here’s some info on how to read geometry data from OnShape:

Steps to Import Onshape Files into Altair Inspire:

Open Altair Inspire/SimSolid: Launch your Altair Inspire or SimSolid software.

Open Altair Inspire/SimSolid: Launch your Altair Inspire or SimSolid software.

Access the Import Tool: On the main toolbar, click the “Import” button, which may be labeled as “Import from PDM system” or “Import from cloud”.

Access the Import Tool: On the main toolbar, click the “Import” button, which may be labeled as “Import from PDM system” or “Import from cloud”.

Select the Onshape Tab: In the dialog box that appears, choose the “Onshape” tab.

Select the Onshape Tab: In the dialog box that appears, choose the “Onshape” tab.

Set Up Your Onshape Credentials: If it’s your first time, click the Settings button to authorize your Onshape account. Select the Authorize in Default Browser button and follow the prompts to log in to your Onshape account and grant access to Altair. Return to the Altair settings dialog and paste the credentials back in.

Set Up Your Onshape Credentials:

If it’s your first time, click the Settings button to authorize your Onshape account.

If it’s your first time, click the Settings button to authorize your Onshape account.

Select the Authorize in Default Browser button and follow the prompts to log in to your Onshape account and grant access to Altair.

Select the Authorize in Default Browser button and follow the prompts to log in to your Onshape account and grant access to Altair.

Return to the Altair settings dialog and paste the credentials back in.

Return to the Altair settings dialog and paste the credentials back in.

Refresh and Browse: Click the Refresh Cloud button to update the list of your Onshape documents. You can now browse and search for your specific Onshape documents.

Refresh and Browse:

Click the Refresh Cloud button to update the list of your Onshape documents.

Click the Refresh Cloud button to update the list of your Onshape documents.

You can now browse and search for your specific Onshape documents.

You can now browse and search for your specific Onshape documents.

Select and Load Your Model: Choose the desired Onshape document from the list. A list of associated Part and Assembly studios will appear in the bottom pane. Double-click on the desired Part or Assembly studio, or select it and click the Open button to load the geometry into your current Altair project.

Select and Load Your Model:

Choose the desired Onshape document from the list.

Choose the desired Onshape document from the list.

A list of associated Part and Assembly studios will appear in the bottom pane.

A list of associated Part and Assembly studios will appear in the bottom pane.

Double-click on the desired Part or Assembly studio, or select it and click the Open button to load the geometry into your current Altair project.

Double-click on the desired Part or Assembly studio, or select it and click the Open button to load the geometry into your current Altair project.

This process allows you to directly pull your Onshape designs into Inspire for analysis, generative design, or other simulation tasks.

Hope this helps!

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: There is no “native file type” for Onshape, as it is a cloud-only software. Use the export tool in Onshape to export a STEP file instead.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: I’m probably missing something here but i don’t see why being cloud-only software would eliminate the need for a custom file-type. Don’t the model files still have to be stored in a way that’s specific to the platform in order to edit it properly?

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked:
Internal to Onshape’s systems, there are probably data structures that kinda look like a CAD file (DWG, SLDPRT, IPT, PRT, etc.). However, these data structures are not meant to be stored locally on a customer’s computer like other CAD programs. They are instead stored on Onshape’s servers for cloud access only. As such, you will never be able to download an “Onshape file”, just the non-parametric neutral files like STEP and STL that are used to communicate “dumb” shape information between programs.

(Unless you’re a huge enterprise customer that’s willing to pay for Onshape to host your data on your own servers)

posts.name: C.Villano
posts.cooked: Changing to the STEP file worked! Thank you for your suggestion!
